synthesis of the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) ZIF-8/GO, (b) ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO, (c–e) ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO, and (f) ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. (g–j) TEM images, (k–n) HRTEM images and (o) EDS mapping of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. Fig. 3 (a) XRD patterns, (b) the Raman spectrum and (c) Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm profiles of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. (d) Full XPS survey spectrum of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. XPS spectra of (e) Co 2p and (f) Zn 2p of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. (g) C 1s spectrum, (h) N 1s and (i) Se 3d spectrum of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. Fig. 4 (a) Cycling test for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO at 100 mA g−1. (b) Rate test for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. (c) Charge-discharge profiles of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. (d) The Long-term cycle stability test of two electrodes at a high current density of 2000 mA g−1 over 1000 cycles. (e) The Long-term cycle stability test of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO at a high current density of 2000 mA g−1 over 4000 cycles. Fig. 5 (a) Schematic illustration of KPB||ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO full cell configuration. (b) The GCD profiles of PKB cathode, ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode and KPB||ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO full cell at 100 mA g−1. (c) The cycling performance of full cell at 100 mA g−1. Fig. 6 (a) CV profiles of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO at stepwise scan rates. (b, c) The calculated b-value of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode. (d) Capacitive contribution of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO at 0.6 mV s−1. (e) The capacitive contributions proportion of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO with the increasing scan rates. (f, g) GITT test profiles for the two electrodes. Diffusion coefficients of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO calculated from GITT test for (h) charge and (i) discharge process. Fig. 7 The potassium-ion adsorption energies on (a) Carbon layer, (b) CoSe2, and (c) CoSe2/C. (d, e) Potassium migration pathway of CoSe2 and C. (f–h) The potassium diffusion barrier in CoSe2 and C by calculation. The different charge density of (i) CoSe2 and (j) CoSe2/C from side view. DOS of (k) CoSe2 and (l) CoSe2/C. Fig. 8 (a) The charge–discharge profiles of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO for the 1st cycle at 100 mA g−1. (b) Ex-situ XRD characterizations under various discharge–charge states for the 1st cycle. (c) Ex-situ XRD characterizations under various discharge–charge states during the 2nd cycle. (d) Schematic illustration of the conversion reaction of the electrode. Ex-situ-HRTEM, and SAED pattern of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO at selected charge–discharge states: (e and f) deeply discharge to 0.01 V and (g and h) fully charge to 3 V. Fig. 9 SEI layer of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode at selected charge–discharge states: (a) deeply discharge to 0.01 V and (b) fully charge to 3 V. Graphical abstract Multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures confinement effect protects the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion, thereby boosting the long-term cycling performance of the potassium-ion battery, as well as improving the sluggish kinetics. Transition metal selenides are regarded as prospective conversion-reaction anodes for potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) because of their relatively high electrical conductivity, large theoretical specific capacity, abundant resources and low cost. The challenge of the metal selenides originates from a serious volume change during cycling, which induces serious structural collapse and fast capacity degradation. In the present work, the multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures confined bimetallic selenides (ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO) were constructed by a facile MOF-assisted strategy. In such special nano-architectures, N-doped CNTs protect the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion/electrode pulverization, as well as improve the sluggish kinetics. ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode boosts the lifespan of half PIBs with a large discharge specific capacity of 200 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 3800 cycles. The full PIBs battery with ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode as anode and Prussian blue as cathode exhibits well electrochemical performance (151 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles). DFT calculation suggests that the CNTs could change the K+ adsorption energy and decrease K+ diffusion energy barrier, which dramatically enhances K+ storage kinetics. This work offers an effective material engineering approach for designing hierarchical “all-in-one” electrodes with high excellent cycling stability for PIBs. Keywords Conversion-reaction anodes Metal selenides Multi-dimensional carbon Potassium-ion battery 1 Introduction Nowadays, lithium-ion batteries have been extensively applied for electronics devices and electric vehicles (EV) owing to their superior energy density features [1–3]. Nevertheless, the scarcity and non-uniform distribution of lithium resources on the earth motivate a compelling motivation to exploit other competitive metal-ion batteries as alternatives [4–7]. Among these rechargeable metal-ion battery systems, potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) seem to be a future alternative energy storage device and capture considerable research interest because of the relatively low redox potential of K+/K (−2.93 V versus SHE), and earth-abundance of potassium elements [8–11]. The obstacles limiting PIBs practical applications originate from the big radius of K+ (1.38 Å) which induces fast capacity fading and slow kinetics of electrode materials during the K+ insertion/extraction process [12–15]. Conversion-type anode materials are considered more favorable for potassium-ion storage which could avoid the effect of a large ionic radius [16–23]. Among the retrieved conversion anodes, transition metal selenides have been regarded as perspective materials because of their theoretically large storage capacity, high electrochemical activity and electrical conductivity, abundant reserves, and low price [16,17]. Furthermore, the bimetallic selenides display preferable electrochemical performance as compared to mono-metallic selenides benefiting from abundant phase interfaces, rich active sites and enhanced electrical conductivity [20]. Nevertheless, the large volume variations during K+ intercalation/deintercalation process lead to the structural collapse of bimetallic selenides, and eventually induce the fast capacity degradation [24]. The addition of a suitable carbon matrix to confine the nanosize of the transition metal dichalcogenides was considered an effective strategy to alleviate mechanical stress caused by the conversion reaction [16,25,26]. Carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) and graphene, have been extensively investigated in the metal-ion battery field thanks to the superior electrical conductivity, high structural stability and good mechanical properties. To hybridize active metallic selenides with graphene, which could shorten the ion diffusion pathway and create highly accessible channels at the interface, facilitating surface redox pseudo-capacitance and interfacial intercalation pseudo-capacitance, respectively [27]. Moreover, 1D carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) could interconnect a high-conductivity network architecture with good structural integrity. In addition, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) provide a confinement effect which can mitigate the excessive growth and agglomeration of active substances to some extent, consequently providing sufficient active sites for the electrochemical reaction [28]. For example, Liu et al. reported N-doped carbon nanotubes confined CoSe nanoparticles as an efficient K+-storing electrode [16]. Embedding the ultrafine CoSe particles in nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes could reduce the active components to the nanoscale, thereby increasing the rate and cycle performance of the PIBs. Wang et al. dispersed the Co3Se4 nano-crystallites on graphene sheets via a simple hydrothermal process. Profiting from the ultrafine crystallite dispersion, the well-dispersed Co3Se4/GO nano-composite displays more stable cycling stability [25]. Inspired by the above viewpoints, in the present work, 2D rGO sheets were stitched together with ZIF-8@ZIF-67 crystalline at first, and then the ultra-small bimetallic selenides were in situ embedded into N-doped CNT (N-CNTs) through simple high-temperature pyrolysis and selenization process. In such hybrid architectures, multi-dimensional graphitic carbon, including carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene, protect the metallic selenides centers from restacking and aggregation. Benefiting from the multifunctional “all-in-one” complex, the optimized electrode ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO exhibits superior reversible capacities and remarkable lifespan stability, especially at large current densities. Furthermore, ex situ characterizations and density functional theory simulations were performed for an in-depth understanding of the intrinsic potassium storage mechanism, which will give more insights into further design of effective electrode materials for the potassium-ion battery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis methods The ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO composites were synthesized according to previous works [29,30]. For the synthesis of ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO, 135 mg of selenium powder and 90 mg of ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO powder were positioned in two separate quartz boats, respectively, and the temperature was elevated to 650 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1, and the selenium reaction was kept at 650 °C for 2 h. For the fabrication of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO, 1.8 g of dicyandiamide (DCDA) and 0.09 g of ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO powder were added in two separate ceramic boats. It should be noted that DCDA was positioned at the upstream side of the furnace. The reaction was first heated at 430 °C for 8 h and then raised to 700 °C and maintained at 700 °C for 4 h. Finally, the samples were calcined with selenium powder in a tube furnace in a weight ratio of 1:1.5 under argon. The details of the materials synthesis process, characterization technique, electrochemical test for half potassium-ion battery, and DFT calculations were shown in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Full potassium-ion battery For the synthesis of prussian blue materials [31,32], 0.4265 g of K4Fe(CN)6⋅3H2O and 0.3270 g of FeCl3 were separately added into deionized water. Then, the solution of FeCl3 was dropwise added into the K4Fe(CN)6 solution with continuous stirring for 2 h. Afterward, the reaction system was aged for 1 day at room temperature and then the blue precipitates were gathered and dried in the vacuum oven at 60 °C. Finally, K0.72Fe[Fe(CN)6] was electrochemically obtained by discharging K0.22Fe[Fe(CN)6] to 2 V in a half cell with K foil as the counter electrode. For making K0.72Fe[Fe(CN)6] (PB) electrode, a slurry was first prepared by distributing K0.22Fe[Fe(CN)6] precursor, Ketjen black, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent with a weight ratio of 70:20:10. Then the slurry was coated on Al foil and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, a half PIB was assembled with 3 M of KFSI in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1, v/v) as electrolyte, K as counter electrode and the above coated K0.22Fe[Fe(CN)6] as working electrode. The half-cell was finally discharged to 2 V to obtain cathode. For a full PIB, it was assembled with ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO as anode, 3 M of KFSI in EC/ DEC (1:1, v/v) as electrolyte and PB as cathode; the mass ratio for anode and cathode is kept at 1.0: 1.05. The amount of electrolyte for each coin battery is around 150 μL both half-cell and full-cell. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterizations The fabrication route of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO is displayed in Fig. 1 . ZIF-8 nanocubes adhere on the surface of GO layer because of the electrostatic interactions between the oxygen-based functional groups and the Zn2+. The CoCl2 solution and 2-MeIm were further adding to the above ZIF-8 suspension in order to obtain ZIF-8@ZIF-67 nanocubes modified GO layer (ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO). The as-prepared ZIF-8@ZIF-67/GO powder was pyrolyzed at 700 °C under Ar gas with the addition of DCDA. During the high-temperature reaction process, GO layer became rGO sheets, and Co2+ and Zn2+ were reduced to metallic Co and Zn phase, respectively (Fig. S1), while the N-containing organic ligands changed into N-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs) (Fig. S2). Finally, N-doped CNTs confined metallic selenide nanoparticles (ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO) were obtained via calcination treatment with Se powder. According to a previous publication [33–35], ZIF-8@ZIF-67 decomposed accompanied by the conversion of imidazole ligands to carbon species and the reduction of Co/Zn ions into Co/Zn metal nanoparticles. The Co species can further catalyze the transformation of carbon species to graphitic carbon nanotubes at high temperature [33,34]. The evaporation of Zn at high pyrolysis temperature accelerates the growth of CNTs [35]. Furthermore, dicyandiamide (DCDA) favors the formation of CNTs at relatively low temperature due to its inducing effect on graphitic structure [33]. In addition, the nitrogen content, the diameter and the formation temperature of the CNTs could be tuned by the ratio of ZIF precursor and dicyandiamide (DCDA). The field emission scanning electron microscopy show ZIF-8 nanocubes are tightly anchored on both sides of GO, suggesting a strong interaction (Fig. 2 a). The ZIF-8@ZIF-67 nanocubes with a polyhedral morphology are also grown on the surface of the GO layer (Fig. 2b). After the high-temperature carbonization process, plenty CNTs are uniformly anchored on the surface of GO layers and the cobalt nanoparticles are encapsulated at the tips of the CNTs (Fig. 2c). After selenization treatment, metallic selenide nanoparticles are confined in the N-doped CNTs (Fig. 2d and e), which can restrain the aggregation during long-term cycling. TEM images confirm that numerous multi-walled N-CNTs are distributed on the rGO layers, and the ZnSe and CoSe2 nanoparticles are confined inside the CNTs (Fig. 2g–j). The HRTEM images reveal the heterostructure characteristics of the CoSe2 and ZnSe phase (Fig. 2k–n). The interplanar distance of 0.20 nm and 0.29 nm are attributed to the (220) and (101) planes of ZnSe and CoSe2, respectively [36]. The interplanar distance of the outside shell is 0.34 nm which can be attributed to the (002) layer of graphite carbon [37]. The phase boundary between CoSe2 and ZnSe could be observed in Fig. 2(m). The boundary (interfacial effect) between CoSe2 and ZnSe phase could accelerate the kinetics for the diffusion of potassium ions in the electrodes [38]. In addition, the (311) plane of CoSe2 and (200) plane of ZnSe are clearly shown in Fig. 2(n) [39]. Furthermore, the elemental mapping images confirm the N are homogeneously distributed in the entire CNTs, and the ZnSe and CoSe2 nanoparticles are confined inside CNTs (Fig. 2o). ICP analysis was performed to illustrate the content ratio of ZnSe/CoSe2 in ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. As exhibited in Table S1, the atomic ratio of ZnSe/CoSe2 is about 7:1 for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO while ∼4:1 for ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. The enlarged EDS mapping in Fig. S3 proves the existence of Zn element in the sample. EDS analysis was used to estimate the C and N content in ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO (Fig. S4). X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO are shown in Fig. 3 (a). The peaks located at 27.43°, 45.40° and 53.43° match well with the (111), (220), (311) planes of ZnSe (JCPDS 37-1463), and the peaks at 30.75°, 34.46°, 35.92°, 47.63° and 50.13° can be attributed to the (101), (111), (120), (211), (002) planes of CoSe2 (JCPDS 53-0449), suggesting the coexistence of CoSe2 and ZnSe phases in both ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO samples [40]. The broad diffraction peak at about 26° in the XRD patterns of the two materials may be derived from the (002) plane of graphitic carbon [41]. The Raman spectroscopy can further analyze the structural composition of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. As displayed in Fig. 3(b), the peaks at ∼1351 and 1589 cm−1 could correspond to the typical D-band and G-band originating from the sp 3- and sp 2-hybridized graphitic carbon [42]. The I D/I G ratios reflect the degree of lattice defect of carbon atoms. The I D/I G ratio of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO (1.03) is larger than that of ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO (1.02), indicating an obvious increase of carbon disorder and defects density for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. Carbon disorder and defects would facilitate charge transfer and offer more reaction sites for the K-ion storage simultaneously [43]. Fig. 3(c) demonstrate N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. The as-prepared samples present a typical IV adsorption–desorption isotherm curve. The distinct hysteresis loop of relative pressure (P/P 0) arises in the range of 0.48–0.98, indicating the existence of mesoporous structure. The specific surface area of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO are 73.5 and 67.1 m2 g−1, respectively. The pore size distribution curve centered at 50 nm also suggests the mesoporous structure. For conversion anode, the large surface area not only enable sufficient contact between electrode and electrolyte but also create enormous sites for redox reactions. The characteristics of mesoporous architectures accelerate the charge transfer process, which is helpful to the superior rate capability [44]. The chemical compositions and valence states of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO sample were exploited by XPS. XPS survey spectrum in Fig. 3(d) confirms the existence of Zn, Co, C, N, and Se elements. For Co 2p spectrum, two peaks at 780.8 and 796.8 eV and the two satellite peaks at 786.8 eV and 801.9 eV correspond to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 of Co2+ in CoSe2, respectively (Fig. 3e) [45]. For the Zn 2p spectrum (Fig. 3f), the two peaks located at 1022.0 eV and 1045.1 eV can be attributed to Zn2+ in ZnSe [46]. Compared with ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO, the Co 2p peaks in ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO migrate to lower binding energy, while the 2p peaks of Zn element move to larger binding energy. The migrations of binding energy could be attributed to defects and lattice distortion at the CoSe2 and ZnSe interface. The rich crystal defects induced by bimetallic selenide phase boundaries could introduce more active sites for potassium-ion cooperation. In addition, the electron density of CoSe2 could enhance owing to the electron-mobility from ZnSe to CoSe2 for charge compensation and thus benefit the reaction kinetics [47–49]. For N 1s spectrum, the three peaks at 398.7, 400.5, and 403.8 eV are related to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and oxidized N, respectively (Fig. 3h). N dopants could enhance the electrical conductivity of graphitic carbon. Furthermore, pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N produce many defects and active sites which favor potassium ion storage performance [50]. As exhibited in Fig. 3(g), in the C 1s spectrum, three peaks at 287.1, 285.8, and 284.8 eV could be ascribed to CO, CN, and CC bonds respectively, confirming the successful introduction of N element into the graphitic carbon. In Fig. 3(i), the two peaks that appeared at 55.1 eV and 56.1 eV could be attributed to Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 1/2, respectively [51,52]. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The potassium storage performance of the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO as an anode material was then evaluated using a 2032-type coin cell assembled with a metallic potassium foil as the reference electrode. The cycle voltammetry (CV) scans for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO were measured at the scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 ranging from 0.01 to 3.0 V, as displayed in Fig. S6(a). For the first cathodic scan, an intensive reduction peak (1.57 V) corresponds to K+ insertion to form K x CoSe2 and the conversion reaction for converting K x CoSe2 into Co and K2Se [25]. For the 1st discharge process, the reduction peak at 0.68 V corresponds to the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film at the electrode and electrolyte interface. The cathodic peak at 0.24 V could be ascribed to the reaction process of ZnSe phase and K+ to produce metal Zn and K2Se. During the first anode scan, the peaks at 2.13 V and 1.75 V were ascribed to the oxidation reaction process of K2Se intermediate with the metal Zn and Co phase, respectively, returning back to CoSe2 and ZnSe phase [20,36]. For the 4th and 5th curves, the two peaks could be ascribed to the various steps of the conversion process, and the highly overlapping characteristics demonstrate the superior reversibility of the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode. Fig. 4 (a) demonstrates the cycling performance of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO electrodes at a current density of 100 mA g−1. The ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode presents a reversible specific discharge capacity of 360 mAh g−1 at 5th cycles, and 343 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, with the retention of 95%. The ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO anodes display the reversible capacities of 382 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, also with the retention of 97%. The long-term cycling behavior at a large current density of 2000 mA g−1 is further estimated. As revealed in Fig. 4(d and e), ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode keeps a high reversible discharging specific capacity of 200 mAh g−1 even after 3800 cycles, with the high retention up to 98%. Comparatively speaking, the ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO electrodes decays significantly during the first 400 cycles, after which it only exhibits a low discharging capacity of 40 mAh g−1, with a retention of 15%. Benefiting from the CNTs effectively inhibits the agglomeration and significantly accommodate the volume expansion of metallic selenide nanoparticles, the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode boosts the long-term cycling performance of the potassium storage process. Fig. S7 shows the SEM images and TEM images of two electrodes after long-term cycling. The morphology of CNTs is maintained, and the metal selenides are still encapsulated into the CNTs, indicating the stability of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode. The typical K+ charge/discharge profiles of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO for 1st, 2nd, 20th, 50th and 100th at a current density of 100 mA g−1 are exhibited in Fig. S6(b). The curves almost overlap after 2th cycle, further revealing the excellent reversibility of the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode. As summarized in Tables S1 and S2, the long-term cycling behavior of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode is superior to the previously reported ZnSe and CoSe2 anode in potassium-ion battery. It could be attributed to the confinement of CNTs protecting the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion/electrode pulverization [16,20,27,51,53–59]. Fig. 4(b) illustrates the rate capability of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO and ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO. For ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO, it performs excellent rate performance with discharge capacities of 355.0, 333.3, 306.1, 276.8, 241.2 and 188.9 mAh g−1 at different current densities, respectively. The specific discharge capacity recovers to 337.5 mAh g−1 when the current density set back to 100 mA g−1, with the retention of 96%. For ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO, the discharge capacities are 408.3, 383.0, 355.3, 302.7, 264.7, and 216.3 mAh g−1 at various current densities and the capacity restores to 410.7 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1. Besides, the charge/discharge curves of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode are listed in Fig. 4(c). The charge and discharge curves under the increasing current density almost do not change, further confirming the superior rate performance of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode [52]. The electrochemical performance of different ZnSe/CoSe2 ratios for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO were provided in Fig. S8. The ratio of ZnSe/CoSe2 has a great influence on the cycling and rate performance, and the sample with starting feed ratio (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O to CoCl2·6H2O) of 1:2 exhibits the best performance. The ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO with different electrolyte systems were exhibited in Fig. S9. The superior potassium-storage ability of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO in half-battery motivates us to further estimate its potential practical in full-battery. The full-cells were assembled with potassium Prussian blue (KPB) as cathode and ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO as anode, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 5 (b), the charge/discharge plateaus of potassium Prussian blue cathode in a half cell appears at about 3.6 and 3.4 V, respectively. The potassium-ion are extracted from the potassium Prussian blue cathode and inserted into the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode during the reversible process. The tested voltage window of the as-assembled full cell was ranging from 1.5 V to 4.0 V. During the 1st cycle, the discharge/charge capacities of the full-cell are 316 mAh g−1 and 105 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1, corresponding to the coulombic efficiency of 33%. For the 50th cycle, the discharge capacity is 118 mAh g−1 and the charge capacity is 123 mAh g−1, respectively, indicating the coulombic efficiency increases to 96%. The full PIBs battery also exhibits well cycling performance with a discharge capacity of 151 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles. 3.3 Electrochemical reaction mechanism To initially explore the kinetic process and mechanism of potassium storage for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode, the CV profiles at various scanning rates ranging from 0.2 mV s−1 to 1.0 mV s−1 were implemented (Fig. 6 a). With the increasing scanning rate, the original shape of the profiles is well maintained, revealing the electrode material with low electrochemical polarization. The linear relationship between the peak current (i) and scan rate (v) can be calculated using the following calculation formulas [60,61]. (1) i = a v b (2) log ( i ) = b log ( v ) + log ( a ) where the b-value can reflect K-ion storage behaviors. When the calculated b-value is near 0.5, K-ion storage is mainly contributed by diffusion-controlled electrochemical behavior; when b-value is approaching 1.0, the capacity is entirely controlled by an ideal pseudocapacitive effect. For ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode, the b values for anodic and cathodic current peaks are 0.93 and 0.88, respectively (Fig. 6b and c), revealing that the pseudocapacitive-controlled behavior occupies a large proportion in a potassium-storage mechanism. Furthermore, the ratio of different capacitance contributions is calculated by the following calculation formula [61]. (3) i( v ) = k 1 v + k 2 v 1/2 where k 1 v and k2v 1/2 present the proportion of capacitance-controlled and diffusion-controlled process, respectively. By integral calculation, the capacitive contribution of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode at 0.6 mV s−1 reaches 76% (Fig. 6d). The capacitive contribution ratios are 64% at 0.2 mV s−1, 73% at 0.4 mV s−1, 79% at 0.8 mV s−1, and 80% at 1.0 mV s−1, respectively (Fig. 6e). The capacitance-controlled characteristics ensure fast charging and discharging rate and superior cycling stability. The high pseudocapacitive contribution ratio could be attributed to the ultrafine metallic selenides in the nanocomposite benefiting from the confinement of CNTs. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was performed for revealing detailed reaction kinetics for the K+ intercalation/deintercalation processes (Fig. 6f and g). As displayed in Fig. 6(h), for ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO electrode, the D k+ value is ranging from 1.41 × 10−10 to 3.09 × 10−9 cm2 S−1 in discharge process and 1.4 × 10−9 to 3.35 × 10−9 cm2 S−1 during charging process. More interestingly, for ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode, the D k+ value scopes from 4.12 × 10−9 to 1.77 × 10−8 cm2 S−1 in discharge process and 7.11 × 10−9 to 1.16 × 10−8 cm2 S−1 during charging process. It is worth noting that ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO presents relatively higher D K + than ZnSe/CoSe2/rGO, implying fast electrode kinetics of ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO. The confinement effect of CNTs could protect the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion/electrode pulverization, enhance the electrical conductivity, as well as improve the sluggish kinetics. To investigate the impact of multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures confinement effect, DFT calculations were conducted for C, CoSe2, and the CoSe2/C nanocomposites. As displayed in Fig. 7 (a–c), the K-adsorption energy is much lower than that of individual C and CoSe2, confirming that the combination of multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures with metallic selenides is more beneficial for the adsorption of K atoms from the point of energy. Fig. 7(f–h) displays the possible migration pathways of K+ to reveal the effect of multi-dimensional carbon matrix on the ion/electron conductivity of the electrode. The K+ diffusion barrier of the C (0.06 eV) is obviously smaller than that of CoSe2 (0.25 eV). Therefore, introducing a carbon layer can efficiently decrease the diffusion energy barrier and accelerate the diffusion of potassium ions [62]. Fig. 7(i and j) shows the charge density difference of CoSe2 and CoSe2/C, in which the yellow and cyan electron clouds show accumulation and depletion of electrons, respectively. K loses electrons when adsorbed CoSe2 and CoSe2/C surfaces. Bader charge analysis indicates that the introduction of C will promote partial electron transfer to C, which is propitious to enhance the interaction between C and CoSe2 [63,64]. Meanwhile, the enhancement of adsorption of CoSe2/C on K can be attributed to the cooperation of C and CoSe2. Furthermore, in order to study the electronic properties of CoSe2 and CoSe2/C, the density of states (DOS) was calculated. As shown in Fig. 7(k), CoSe2 exhibited a metallic characteristic. The carbon nano-architectures affect the metallic characteristic of CoSe2 phase and enhance the ion/electron transport to a certain extent, which is beneficial to fast potassium-ion diffusion kinetics and superior rate performance [20]. In addition, ex situ XRD, and ex situ HRTEM were carried out to reveal the potassium-ion storage mechanism of the ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode. Fig. 8 (a) shows the XRD patterns gathered at various discharge/charge states. The peaks of Parafilm appear at 36.5° and 45.0°, and the peak of Cu foil emerges at 43.5° [63]. During the first cycle, after discharging to 1.2 V, the peaks of ZnSe and CoSe2 disappear, and new peaks at 22.5 and 37.2° corresponding to metal Co appear, indicating the conversion reaction related to CoSe2 occurs [65]. After discharging to 0.3 V, the appearance of the metal Zn peak indicates that the conversion reaction of ZnSe takes place. After deeply discharging to 0.01 V, the peaks of K2Se and Co phase could be observed [43,66]. As displayed in Fig. 8(e), the diffraction rings corresponding to the crystal planes of Co and Se planes could be detected in SAED pattern. The Se phase comes from the formation of K2Se process [67]. Ex situ XRD patterns for the 2nd cycle are also displayed in Fig. 8(c). During the discharge process, the peak of K2CoSe2 at 25.7° and the peak of ZnSe at 45.4° gradually weaken and disappear. When discharged to 0.3 V, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Co, K5Se3, and K2Se can be observed, indicating the conversion reaction of K2CoSe2 to Co and K5Se3/K2Se occurs. After deeply discharging to 0.01 V, the peaks of K5Se3 and Zn could be observed which indicates that the conversion reaction of ZnSeto Zn and K5Se3 takes place [66]. When charged to 3.0 V, the peak intensities of the CoSe2 phase and ZnSe phase can be observed. The origin of K3Se5 phase comes from the decomposition of K2Se [55]. The HRTEM further confirms the above results. After charging to 1.0 V, the peak corresponding to the K2CoSe2 appears. After fully charging to 3.0 V, the peaks corresponding to K2CoSe2 phase become more obvious, and the SAED pattern and ex-situ HRTEM image further confirm this phenomenon (Fig. 8g). It suggests the final charged product is K2CoSe2 [55]. Thereby, the conversion process could be described as follows. Discharge process: (4) CoSe 2 + x K + + x e - → K x CoSe 2 (5) K x CoSe 2 + ( 4 - x ) K + + ( 4 - x ) e - → Co + 2 K 2 Se (6) ZnSe + 2 K + + 2 e - → Zn + K 2 Se Charge process: (7) Co + K 2 Se → K x CoSe 2 + ( 4 - x ) K + + ( 4 - x ) e - (8) K x CoSe 2 → CoSe 2 + x K + + x e - (9) Zn + K 2 Se → ZnSe + 2 K + + 2 e - As shown the Fig. 9 (a), when deeply discharged to 0.01 V, an amorphous film with thickness of 10–15 nm uniformly covers the electrode surface. After charging to 3.0 V, the thickness of the amorphous film is about ∼18 nm (Fig. 9b). The corresponding EDX elemental mapping presents the uniform distribution of C, N, Co, Zn, Se, K, F, O and S elements (Fig. 9c and d), in which the F, O and S elements are mainly derived from the electrolyte decomposition upon the homogeneous construction of the SEI layer. The thickness of SEI layer accords well with the previous works on KFSI/EC + DEC based electrolyte system [68,69]. 4 Conclusions In summary, the multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures confined to bimetallic selenides were constructed by a facile MOF-assisted strategy. The as-prepared ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO anode demonstrates a superior lifespan which could maintain a discharge capacity of 200 mAh g−1 even after 3800 cycles. In a full cell configuration(K0.72Fe[Fe(CN)6]|KSFI-EC/DEC|ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO), the potassium-ion battery displays a stable discharge capacity of 151 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles. The excellent potassium-ion storage performance should be ascribed to two major fundamental reasons: (1) the confinement effect of N-CNTs protects the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion/electrode pulverization, as well as improving the sluggish kinetics. (2) graphitic carbon favors the electrical conductivity of electrodes and fasts the transfer of K+ and electrons. This work provides new insights into the confinement effect for durable and fast electrode materials of potassium storage. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal selenides are regarded as prospective conversion-reaction anodes for potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) because of their relatively high electrical conductivity, large theoretical specific capacity, abundant resources and low cost. The challenge of the metal selenides originates from a serious volume change during cycling, which induces serious structural collapse and fast capacity degradation. In the present work, the multi-dimensional carbon nano-architectures confined bimetallic selenides (ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO) were constructed by a facile MOF-assisted strategy. In such special nano-architectures, N-doped CNTs protect the metal selenides centers from serious volume expansion/electrode pulverization, as well as improve the sluggish kinetics. ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode boosts the lifespan of half PIBs with a large discharge specific capacity of 200 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 3800 cycles. The full PIBs battery with ZnSe/CoSe2@N-CNTs/rGO electrode as anode and Prussian blue as cathode exhibits well electrochemical performance (151 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles). DFT calculation suggests that the CNTs could change the K+ adsorption energy and decrease K+ diffusion energy barrier, which dramatically enhances K+ storage kinetics. This work offers an effective material engineering approach for designing hierarchical “all-in-one” electrodes with high excellent cycling stability for PIBs.
